Video game remasters are now so numerous they’re in danger of earning themselves a bad name. The Tokyo Game Show could be the venue for unveiling both Sony’s updated PS4.5 and Nintendo’s new console, if rumours are true.

A decade or so ago the Tokyo Game Show was a vitally important trade event, but more recently it’s become little more than a side show. But that could be about to change if a report by website VR World is correct.

HD remasters of the first two Shenmue games will happen, but Sega has warned not to expect them any time soon.

Even without the announcement of Shenmue III last year, fans have been calling for proper remasters of Shenmue I and II since forever.

Despite the fame (or is that infamy?) of the games it’s impossible to play them on any current format, with the original only having been released on the Dreamcast and the sequel only on the Dreamcast and original Xbox.

Dark Souls III is fast-selling Souls game ever http://metro.co.uk/2016/05/11/dark-souls-iii-is-fast-selling-souls-game-ever-5875443/ http://metro.co.uk/2016/05/11/dark-souls-iii-is-fast-selling-souls-game-ever-5875443/#respond Wed, 11 May 2016 15:17:26 +0000 http://metro.co.uk/?p=5875443 ]]>

The Dark Souls franchise has now sold over 13 million copies worldwide, with the latest entry already at 3 million.

A series famed for its difficulty and its ruthless demands on players’ time and patience, is exactly the opposite of what you’d expect from a successful mainstream video game. But Dark Souls is different.

Bandai Namco has now shipped 13 million copies of the three games so far, according to a Japanese press release translated by Gematsu.

Over 3 million of those sales are for Dark Souls III, which has reached that milestone… Read the full story]]> http://metro.co.uk/2016/05/11/dark-souls-iii-is-fast-selling-souls-game-ever-5875443/feed/ 0 Dark Souls III - From will be lighting a few bonfires over this news davidjenkins2012 Dark Souls III - what happens next? A point ‘n’ click adventure that mixes the best of LucasArts with more serious storytelling, and one of the year’s most intriguing heroines.

Sadly, the graphic adventure revival is not something that ever really went mainstream. If you count Telltale Games you could argue it did, but they only really became popular once they moved away from the retro LucasArts formula of Monkey Island and Sam & Max. Not only will there will be no Disney Infinity 4.0, but Disney has made the decision to discontinue the franchise, close down its developer, and stop publishing video games.

The Crash Bandicoot games are fondly remembered as some of the best ever seen – with players fondly recalling the bright colours, charming gameplay and distinct levels as peak Playstation.

The earlier games in particular are placed upon a gaming pedestal – and for good reason – but those wearing their rose tinted spectacles are conveniently forgetting the hours of anguish and controller smashing rage the series induced.

Normally docile humans were reduced to quivering beasts as their massive collection of lives was cruelly depleted and, for a time, you vowed never to play again.

They could now be worth a small fortune.

WipEout co-creator wants to make official sequel http://metro.co.uk/2016/05/10/wipeout-co-creator-wants-to-make-official-sequel-5871939/ http://metro.co.uk/2016/05/10/wipeout-co-creator-wants-to-make-official-sequel-5871939/#respond Tue, 10 May 2016 09:30:34 +0000 http://metro.co.uk/?p=5871939 ]]>

Sony may not be interested in making a new WipEout game, but one of the original creators is trying to get it made on his own.

Especially since they shut down the developer, there’s very little chance that Sony is ever going to make another WipEout game. But series co-creator Nick Burcombe has let it be known that he wants to license the name from them and make a new game himself.

Burcombe has just finished work on the Micro Machines-esque Table Top Racing: World Tour, which is currently free to PS Plus subscribers.
